DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil Prices are Causing Problems For the Poor
DOC.TEXT: The coldest December weather in New England in a century is hitting people least able to withstand the blow _ people on fixed incomes and those receiving a specified amount of fuel assistance. But amid rising concern among the poor and increasing calls for investigations by elected officials, there were signs Thursday that the price of home heating oil may drop as rapidly as it rose. The U.S. Department of Energy reported record volumes of heating oil flowing toward the Northeast. The department also granted the first of what it expects to be several waivers allowing foreign ships to carry oil from one U.S. port to another. Existing law restricts such shipments to U.S.-owned vessels. People around the region say help can't come fast enough. ``I have one patient who must have oxygen. This week, she turned it off to save money for fuel,'' said Jeanne Steenbeke, a visiting nurse in the Concord, N.H., area. ``That's kind of scary.'' ``Elderly people have every penny of their Social Security money allotted,'' she said. ``There's X amount of dollars for rent, for food and for utilities.'' Topsy Corcoran, 82, a widow on a fixed income, paid $1.46 a gallon to fill her heating oil tank Wednesday in Concord, N.H. On Thursday, she would have paid $1.52. The last time she filled the tank, it cost almost $100; this time it was $150. ``I've got to pay for it. What am I going to do?'' she said. The Massachusetts fuel assistance program already has received 17,000 applications for aid this year, about 4,000 more than it received any previous year, said Ed McCauley, program director. McCauley said some 643 households on aid have already run out of their allotted funds for the winter because of the high price of heating oil. ``Those people are in trouble right now,'' he said. Federal Energy Department spokesman Thomas Olson reported two price drops on the wholesale oil market Thursday. The January price for home heating oil _ the price that wholesalers will pay for future deliveries _ dropped 3 cents per gallon, according to Olson. And the price on the ``prompt'' market in New York Harbor _ the price being paid for oil at the wharf _ dropped 12 cents per gallon. ``It will take a few more days to see if there's a real trend here,'' Olson said. Added Bernard Smith of the New England Fuel Institute, a group that represents fuel delivery companies, ``What goes up will come down. It will probably come down so fast people will hear it.'' Several members of Congress, including U.S. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., and Reps. Bruce Morrison, D-Conn., Christopher Shays, R-Conn., and Joseph Moakley, D-Mass., on Thursday joined the chorus of officials calling on energy Secretary James D. Watkins to investigate the price increases for the possibility of price fixing. But Olson said the department lacks authority over prices and that the attorney general's office would have to conduct such an inquiry. These developments in Washington did little to alleviate the immediate crisis in the cold-bound Northeast. Gary Groleau, energy coordinator for New Hampshire's fuel assistance program, said 1,200 more people have applied for assistance this year than last. Boston's City Hall energy hotline reported record numbers of poor people calling because they've used their fuel assistance allotment already. Jean Fleischman of the Boston-based Citizens Energy Corp., a private foundation that supplies affordable heating oil to the poor, related a tale of winter misery. ``I had an elderly woman yesterday, a widow from East Boston; she ran out of oil and her house was cold,'' Ms. Fleischman said. ``She was crying.''
